summary: Yuri Ivanovich Nosenko was a KGB defector who provided information to the FBI in 1964, as detailed in an FBI report from April 7, 1964. His defection and subsequent interviews covered a range of topics, including American tourists and priests in Moscow, potential KGB recruitments, and Soviet intelligence operations. Later, he testified before the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) on June 20, 1978, regarding Lee Harvey Oswald's time in the Soviet Union and the KGB's alleged lack of interest in him. The Department of Defense also provided information to the HSCA concerning Nosenko in relation to the JFK assassination investigation.
significance: Yuri Ivanovich Nosenko is significant in the JFK assassination context because he provided testimony to the HSCA regarding Lee Harvey Oswald's time in the Soviet Union and the KGB's alleged lack of interest in him. As a KGB defector, his insights into Soviet intelligence operations and potential connections to Oswald were considered relevant to the investigation.
